en.question: What is the definition of a near miss and what to do with a near-miss case?
answer: Definition of a near miss โ a failure in treatment, or an error identified before or during performance, that was prevented and did not cause actual harm to the patient.
These events have great educational value and constitute a systemic opportunity to improve treatment safety.
There is great importance in increasing the number of near-miss reports over the number of adverse event reports and thereby preventing the next event.
In every near-miss case the event must be checked or investigated and conclusions drawn accordingly, in order to prevent the next event.

en.question: All staff members know how to report the location of a fire extinguisher and rules of conduct in case of fire
answer: *In any suspicion of an event (visible fire, smoke, smell) in the department or upon hearing alarm detectors as a warning of fire outbreak in the department, split teams to locate and immediately verify the exact location.
*Whoever discovered the fire: remove people in the fire/smoke area โ patients and visitors.
*Extinguish the fire independently using the firefighting equipment available in the department.
*Update the event manager in the department
*Department event manager: call security center 8100 or alternatively activate the fire button.
*Senior person on site: during regular working hours โ hospital management. During on-call hours โ the general nurse.

en.question: For an isolated patient: is the appropriate equipment available at the entrance to the room? What equipment should be allocated to a patient in contact isolation?
answer: For a patient in contact isolation or in a cohort area, separate equipment / devices are allocated (blood pressure monitor, glucometer, etc.).
For a patient in contact isolation the equipment at the entrance to the room: alcohol hand sanitizer, single-use gloves, single-use gowns, collectors, designated waste bins.
